content: greetings from the forest of winter we got snow here and it is looking
beautiful it's a good time to start making some winter terrain
I made this simple snow terrain together
with my friend Jacob we started this project by cutting ourselves a suitable
piece of foam this is XPS foam used for insulating
houses check out the links in the descriptions for more info first we
planned a bit a path leads up here to the top where we'll place some
structures stones and trees I started by cutting out the path using my
professional crafting knife when doing these cuts you don't need to be worried
about messy cuts as all of this will be covered later do worry about your
fingers they are quite useful after a while of cutting it should look
something like this here is a miniature for scale we then cut away material from
this side in order to create a slope here okay this is how we will build this
some stone formations scattered around made from bark and a stone floor
surrounded by ruined pillars just a rough plan we started with the stone
floor we cut out a thin piece for the floor and then carved in simple stones
with a pencil after that we made the usual stone textures with a ball of
aluminum foil there we go since most of the surfaces will be
covered with snow later we don't really have to care at all we just glued in the
floor using hot glue and we filled all the gaps using foam scraps actually we
didn't feel of much at all part of the experiment is to see if the snow can
cover all of this here we have the stone pillars made in the same way as the
floor we glue these around the floor one for each corner yeah this one fits
perfectly
at this point we were convinced this will be epic
next we glued in a few bricks of foam around some of the pillars this is good
just to get a more ruined look and to add some cover for the miniatures these
were also textured using the aluminum foil then we poked in a few simple dead
trees just twigs assembled together using hot glue
moving on to the stones we used bark and pebbles for this first we made a
diagonal cut for most of the bark bits and then glued them onto the piece by
using leftover XPS foam beads as support then the pebbles we just placed this
around wherever we felt like it would be good we also ran out of hot glue just
for the purpose of showing you that PVA glue also works well for this hmm
this still looks kind of like a cake decorated by toddlers fear not we'll add
more sand and rubble flocking before the flocking we quickly shaped the
soon-to-be rocky cliffs using knives we just ripped out a bit to create an
uneven surface okay we'll use my chopped up bark
flocking first we applied lots of PVA glue will cover the cliffsides first
after the PVA glue was spread out nicely we sprinkled on the bark chop it as
always sand is also good for this but won't smell as good the flat surfaces
will also be covered with flocking but of smaller drain size so we chopped up
some more if you do this keep in mind the different grain sizes are easily
separated by shaking we then covered the rest of the surfaces with glue yeah this
build is gonna be like 50% PVA glue just wait for the snow okay we applied the
fine bark toppings and let this dry for a while as you can see here we didn't
cover exactly everything we will still add the snow later so bald spots will
not be charged we then put the cake in the oven the glue dries a bit faster if
it's warm to seal in the flock we made a base coat from roof paint PVA glue and a
bit of week old painting water perfect usually regular acrylic craft paints are
good I just found this bucket of paint and thought I'd give it a try again
since there will be a lot of snow not all crevasses need to be fully
painted we made sure to spread it out well leaving a thin coat that doesn't
take ages to dry then we painted the stonework with black the platform
pillars and the bricks the rocks were also painted with a dark blue it will be
a bit less blue when the paint dries the base coating is done time to paint
we over brushed the stone platform with gray then painted of the pillars left
sides and stones with the same gray moving on to the flat surfaces we over
brushed the ground with brown first this paint job is looking a bit glossy
perhaps the roof paint should go on the roof instead but we'll see then we
covered the trees with brown with a too large brush dry brushing we dry brushed
everything except the trees with a tan this will be a super simple paint job
here the camera freaks out due to the slight gloss but the dry brushing on the
stonework was captured well after a while we thought this needs some
washes first a dark-brown wash a bit everywhere the wash darkens cracks and
crevices effectively adding depth to the piece also the brown adds some color to
the piece on some parts you can just let it flow down naturally that should look
good next we made a blueish wash the wash is
just mixed from paints water and a few drops of detergent easy to make at home
the glossy issue is also fixed now I place the lights straight above the
camera here the blue wash adds a bit of much-needed color variations to the
rocks this is basically reverse dry brushing but don't quote me on that one
well this looks better now we dry brush the trees before consulting the forsaken
snow schematics we didn't focus too much on the trees time to make the snow it is
made from baking soda PVA glue white paint and some water first we added
baking soda a spoonful for the two first batches and two spoonfuls for the third
batch we will try three different batches to increase the flu factor of
the snow next we added PVA glue roughly one tablespoon in volume well that's not
so scientific take that Americans I'll make a tutorial with exact imperial
units later perhaps when I make the base for a thought slayer Santa good now the
white paint just an arbitrary amount equal to one generous tablespoon then we
added water into the first and third batch and proceeded by mixing to see
what happens it seemed that all batches needed more baking soda well screw the
scientific approach we just kept adding soda to the water free - until it was
fluffy as seen in here as I said more of the snow in an upcoming episode until
then you can just experiment and have fun next up the fun part we applied the
fluffy snow paste using a brush this stuff can be used to create
no formations with quite impressive volume at first we weren't quite sure
how this will turn out but we just kept adding more we added it on the stones
and trees as well here you can see if the snow has great coverage we were able
to hide all of our mistakes we applied varying coverage over the entire piece
not forgetting the top of the pillars of course after some painting and mixing of
more snow stuff we ended up with a nice snow covered piece the pentagram is
missing painted we began by painting rough outlines of the pentagram using
dark bloody red next from these paints and diluted in a bit of water
our freehand sucks but we managed we painted the symbol with red in the
middle and worked with the diluted dark red to make the outer edges a bit darker
okay the snow seems to be really solid when
it dries more texture is revealed will the heroes be in time to stop Satan
Claus from finishing the dreaded chaos ritual or will darkness conquer
will you join the path of crafting do that right now by subscribing to Bart's
craft and I'll show you how to craft more simple terrain and miniatures
